One other issue is that coverage (even path coverage) follows a classic int=
erpretation of "paths" being based on the structure of the code.  But for a=
n exception throwing language there is other possible "paths" that are trig=
gered by behavior of the called code.  Consider:
  public static void int parse (String s) {
    return Integer.parseInt(s);
  }
Classically this has exactly one code path and gets 100% coverage if you p=
ass in "1234" but behaviorally it has two paths because parseInt can throw =
an exception.  So ... you really need "data coverage" which is a nebulous c=
oncept to measure at best.
=20
Kent
 =20

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of C=

Sent: Wednesday, November 16, 2005 5:58 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] coverage testing


On 11/16/05, Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
>
> On 16/11/05, C=C3=A9dric Beust =E2=99=94 <cbeust@...> wrote:
> > Nobody disputes that 100% code coverage is a good thing, it's just tha=
t
> it
> > becomes impossibly hard to achieve as your code base becomes more
> complex.
> > You just need to make sure you don't hit the point of diminishing retu=
rn
> > when trying to hit a balance between "more code coverage", "more tests=
",
> > "bug fixes" and "more features".
>
> The other part, of course, is that 100% code coverage still doesn't
> mean you've tested everything... there will still be logic paths
> through the code that are not exercised, and in any large enough
> program (say, above 10000 lines), these paths rapidly approach
> infiinty.


Great point, and one that is often neglected by code coverage enthusiasts.

--
C=C3=A9dric
